items.title: U.S. ambassador downplays fears of Trump administration meddling in Canadian politics
Israel approves hundreds of housing units in 3 settlements in the occupied West Bank
items.summary_auto: Israel has given the go-ahead for the construction of 764 more houses in three Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, a decision likely to further stoke tensions as a watchdog group accused the Israeli government of moving toward "de facto annexation" of the Palestinian territory.

items.title: Alberta emergency rooms hit with wave of influenza patients
items.summary_auto: Alberta hospitals are being slammed with flu patients at a time when they’re already under strain, and doctors are bracing for more as the worst of the respiratory virus season has yet to hit.

items.title: Trump’s point man on trade floats separate deals with Canada and Mexico
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump’s lead trade negotiator says the administration is considering breaking up the three-way free trade agreement with Canada and Mexico, moving toward separate deals instead.

items.title: Iceland will boycott Eurovision in protest of Israel's participation
items.summary_auto: Spain, the Netherlands, Ireland and Slovenia have also announced their plans to boycott the event, citing Israel's conduct in its war against Hamas in Gaza. This comes after the European Broadcasting Union, made up of a number of European public broadcasters, cleared Israel to participate last week.

items.title: 'Slow down,' say police after 2 officers injured while responding to 400 southwestern Ontario crashes
items.summary_auto: Two police officers were among the multiple people injured as treacherous road conditions resulted in more than 400 reported crashes early Wednesday in southwestern Ontario.

items.title: Quebec cracks down on organized crime, high-risk sex offenders and protests in new bill
items.summary_auto: Quebec's Public Security Minister Ian Lafrenière tabled a bill Wednesday aiming to create a public registry for high-risk sex offenders, prevent protests from taking place too close to the homes of elected officials and crack down on members of organized crime groups who show off their groups' logos or patches.

items.title: Anti-corruption police launch investigation into allegations of Quebec Liberals' wrongdoings
items.summary_auto: Quebec's anti-corruption police have launched a criminal investigation into the Quebec Liberals' wrongdoing allegations.

items.title: Brothers locked in rooms for 18 hours, restrained with zip ties overnight, co-accused tells Ont. murder trial
items.summary_auto: Brandy Cooney was back testifying Tuesday at the Milton, Ont., murder trial for her and her wife, with the Crown challenging Cooney’s earlier narrative that she and Becky Hamber loved and cared for two brothers under their care and rarely used restraints.

items.title: Dillon Dube, player acquitted in Hockey Canada sexual assault trial, joining Blues' AHL affiliate
items.summary_auto: Dillon Dube, the only remaining unsigned player among the five members of Canada's 2018 world junior team who were acquitted of sexual assault in the high-profile case, has agreed to an American Hockey League professional tryout with the St. Louis Blues.

items.title: Pro-Palestinian activist Yves Engler barred from running for NDP leadership
items.summary_auto: Self-described "agitator" Yves Engler says he has been denied entry into the NDP leadership race.

items.title: Customers line up at Manitoba Liquor Marts for 1st chance to buy American liquor in months
With the Grinch behind bars, this N.L. MP brings 'jail not bail' message to local Christmas parade
items.summary_auto: Terra Nova-The Peninsulas MP Jonathan Rowe entered a float in the Trinity Bight Christmas parade featuring the Grinch behind bars and under a banner reading "jail not bail." One resident is raising questions about the place of politics in parades, while Rowe is remaining tongue-in-cheek.

items.title: Rwanda-backed M23 rebels say they've seized strategic city of Uvira in east Congo
items.summary_auto: Rwanda-backed rebel group M23 said that it's taken control of the strategic city of Uvira in eastern Congo on Wednesday afternoon, following a rapid offensive since the start of the month.

items.title: Bank of Canada holds key interest rate at 2.25%, saying economy has proved 'resilient'
items.summary_auto: The Bank of Canada is holding its key interest rate at 2.25 per cent, a move that was widely expected by economists after an encouraging round of economic data.

items.title: NHLers 'not going' to Olympics if ice isn’t ready and safe, reiterates deputy commissioner
Sophie Kinsella, author behind Confessions of a Shopaholic books, dead at 55
items.summary_auto: Sophie Kinsella was first diagnosed with an aggressive form of brain cancer in 2022, and revealed the diagnosis in 2024. In a social media post announcing her death, the author’s family said she “took nothing for granted” and battled her illness with courage.

items.title: Alberta passes bill affecting transgender people invoking notwithstanding clause
items.summary_auto: Alberta's governing United Conservatives stayed up into the early pre-dawn hours of Wednesday morning to pass a bill that uses the notwithstanding clause to shield laws affecting transgender youth.

items.title: Prince George, B.C., conservation group fixes deadly problem for Nechako River fish
items.summary_auto: The Spruce City Wildlife Association has reconnected a side channel at Cottonwood Island Park to the Nechako River, restoring a critical fish habitat and preventing fish from being trapped and left to die during periods of low water.

items.title: Ukraine coalition allies speak with Trump as push to revise peace plan continues
items.summary_auto: The leaders of Britain, France and Germany discussed with U.S. President Donald Trump ongoing U.S.-led peace talks for Ukraine, Prime Minister Keir Starmer's office said on Wednesday, welcoming efforts to secure a just and lasting settlement.

items.title: Home is where the swag is: Sask. music fan amasses souvenirs from 1,200 shows
items.summary_auto: Visitors to Roque Andres, Jr.'s house in Saskatoon immediately notice a collection of mementos from decades of attending rock concerts.

items.title: N.S. fishermen concerned sewer outfall will affect harbour livelihoods
items.summary_auto: A pipe expected to carry treated sewage into the south harbour in Ingonish, N.S., has fishermen concerned about the possible impact on fishing in general and their lobster storage operations.

items.title: 13 years later, the IKEA monkey is all grown up — and his sanctuary is at capacity
items.summary_auto: Thirteen years after an attempted escape from an IKEA parking lot, Darwin the monkey has been living out his life at Storybook Primate Sanctuary, the only one of its kind in Canada. He may be shy, but volunteers say he is thriving.

items.title: Beloved children's author Robert Munsch promising dozens of books to come after his death
items.summary_auto: After a lifetime of writing beloved children’s books, Robert Munsch is now living with dementia and Parkinson’s disease. In an exclusive interview that he calls his "last hurrah," the bestselling author tells CBC News chief correspondent Adrienne Arsenault about the world that shaped his stories, revealing a secret plan to release dozens of books after his death.

items.title: Is Trump’s stark new security strategy the end of the liberal world order? Europeans will need convincing
items.summary_auto: European leaders must decide whether to reject or embrace the conclusions of U.S. President Donald Trump’s new security strategy. It berates and insults them and calls into question some of the key premises of collective security that have helped protect the continent for eight decades.

items.title: U.S. businesses claim Canada is a back door for products from China
items.summary_auto: As U.S. President Donald Trump sticks with tariffs on imports from Canada, some American industries are accusing Canadian competitors of using cheap materials from China in ways that violate free-trade rules and undercut U.S. companies.

items.title: 'Venezuela will breathe again': María Corina Machado's daughter delivers her Nobel Peace Prize speech
items.summary_auto: María Corina Machado dedicated her Nobel Peace Prize to the political prisoners and human rights activists fighting for democracy in Venezuela in a speech delivered by her daughter at a ceremony in Norway on Wednesday.

items.title: Medication to treat postpartum depression approved by Health Canada
items.summary_auto: Health Canada has approved the first drug designed to treat postpartum depression. The regulator says zuranolone, a pill sold under the brand name Zurzuvae, is authorized in Canada to relieve symptoms of moderate or severe depression after childbirth.

items.title: Toronto is Canada's 'rattiest' city, according to new ranking | Hanomansing Tonight
items.summary_auto: Toronto retains its title as the ‘rattiest’ city in Canada, according to the latest ranking from pest control service Orkin Canada. Kaylee Byers, an assistant professor in the school of population and public health at the University of British Columbia, talks to Hanomansing Tonight about tracking rat populations.
